reviewText: The first season of Touch was a revelation.  The violence was minimal.  The story was about connection and oneness.  This season, I guess they wanted better ratings so they added in a serial killer and have been making it all about bad guys trying to use the children for their greedy or evil purposes.  The father started out as almost the opposite of Jack Bauer of 24 (hated guns etc.).  Now J Baum is a crack shot and is able to beat people up (always in self-defense, of course).  It's starting to improve as we get toward the end of the season but it is like most shows now, just with a "supernatural" twist instead of being unique and wonderful.  EVERY episode of the first season made me cry (in a good way).  Every episode was about heroism and beauty.  Now, it's much like the rest of the other dreck on tv but still a bit better because it has some of the original elements in it.  I hope they have a season 3 and I hope they redeem the show.
summary: Not as good as the first season

reviewText: We absolutely love TOUCH and eagerly await each new episode! There is so much to think about, the inter-connectedness of the characters and the twists and turns of the plot lines. I don't "buy" too many shows, but don't have regular TV (only a small antenna) so I gladly pay for these episodes, plus we go back and watch them over again and pick up on clues we missed before. Excellent show all the way around!
summary: This is the best show on TV!

reviewText: Season 2 of "Touch" started off dull with their 1st episode and dragged its feet through the mud and crapper throughout the rest of season 2. The story is soporific and not exciting. In fact, I was so bored after watching the first 15-20 minutes of the 1st episode that I turned it off and considered writing a letter to the producers/writers of this awful show asking what the hell they were thinking when writing the story. Don't waste your time watching this. Instead, if you're itching and burning to watch more of Kiefer Sutherland on television, watch season 1 of "Touch" (a better story line) and, of course, the action-packed drama "24" (which deserves Emmy awards and is making a worthy return to television this May). There, I just saved you hours of your life that would have been wasted watching season 2 of "Touch".
summary: Poor story line and dull writing

reviewText: This was an enjoyable series.  The plot got a little flimsy and less believable in the second season - probably because they weren't getting the ratings that they wanted so they decided to wrap it up.  But, heck, if you enjoyed all the seasons of 24, then Touch won't be any less believable!
summary: Pretty good, but the plot wore a little thin

reviewText: This has been a very nice series but the second season gets away from the connecting story lines that made the first season so much fun to watch. This season is more about the bad guys out to get the good guys. Still, I found the show fun to watch. I do miss the two Japanese girls making an appearance now and then. Keifer Suterland is fine as the the harassed dad just trying to keep his son out of danger but his style of speaking his lines in a whisper can be irritating when he is having a conversation with someone speaking clearly. Turning up the volume when Kiefer is speaking and turning it back down when the other person is speaking in a normal voice can be off-putting. I do not know if thiere will be a third season but I do not expect there will be one. Too bad, the show should have stayed with the concept established in the first season, perhaps it would have picked up a loyal following.

Because Jake is a savant and can see th corrolation and connection of everything through physics and numbers.  Jake does not speak, although they believe he just chooses to not talk.  Great supporting cast as well.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: We watched the first season of Touch, becoming fans of the plot.  The "harmonic convergence" of stories based on an understanding of universal order, creating simultaneous lessening of psychic pain all over the world was an enthralling concept.  We had some questions about  Kiefer Sutherland's script - when would it be more than calling, "Jake!  Jake!".  And we wondered how the parent of such a miracle child could keep leaving him on others' doorsteps in order to go on quests created by that child's needs.  But overall, it was at least a 5 star idea in a 4 star package.  And the possibilities were sure to keep the series going for quite some time.This season is different, sadly.  Did they make the mistake of getting new writers?  Or are we going back to "Heroes"?  Instead of a plot/homage to ideas like "Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close", we are back in shoot-em-up and cloak and dagger themes where Jake is conveniently out of the picture - either at school (who would have thought it) or sitting at a computer in a newspaper office.  Granted, that takes Sutherland away from, "Jake! Jake!"  But it also takes away the magnetic power of the first season.  The tension is still often very well done.  The trouble is, that's about all there is now.
